introduction.p: Two key themes are abstraction and generalization. This includes the flexibility to abstract from arithmetic calculations with specific quantities to algebraic work with symbols representing those quantities. This allows us to move from a very specific situation towards studying other problems that fit a similar pattern.

section.title: From arithmetic to algebra

introduction.p: Previously we discussed a situation where we know we have run for 25 minutes and covered 5 km or \dfrac{25 \text{minutes}}{5 \text{km}} Now, say we ran other races or friends have other times at the same race. Rather than repeat the calculation at each instance, we could think of generalizing this thought process and building a formula that works for any time represented by the value of the symbol x. We would begin by \dfrac{x \text{minutes}}{5 \cancel{\text{km}}}\times\dfrac{1.609 \ cancel{\text{km}}}{1 \text{mi}} = 0.3218x \dfrac{\text{minutes}}{\text{mi}}

section.p: With this we would say that given a time x our pace is given by \text{pace}= 0.3218x \dfrac{\text{minutes}}{\text{mi}} Then we could consider calculations of any reasonable value for x, or time in minutes. For example,

table.title: Pace for a few lengths of time.

section.p: You might notice that multiplication by 0.3218 is a rather specific detail and ask if, as you were running with your eye on the watch, you could do a reasonable job estimating your pace with a simpler calculation. We could argue that 0.3218 \approx 0.333\dots = \sfrac{1}{3} noticing this we might consider 0.3218x\approx\left(\sfrac{1}{3}\right)x and furthermore that multiplication by \sfrac{1}{3} is equivalent to division by 3. We could reasonably approximate our pace by \text{pace} = \sfrac{x}{3} which might be a bit easier than multiplying by 0.3218 in your tired mind.

table.title: Pace for a few lengths of time, but also quickly approximated by a simpler calculation.

section.p: It is worth pointing out that we spend most of our time in math classes (and other classes) looking at problems that we can solve exactly and to a unique answer. This is not the case in almost any real situation. Approximation is valid and valuable as a strategy, we do just need to be aware of the error we introduce and its consequences. Entire fields of advanced mathematics are devoted to such issues. The limitations of doing arithmetic on base-2 computers? That is a big part of numerical analysis. How important is a specific (and often `small') term in a great big formula? That is a big part of perturbation theory.

section.title: From formulas to functions
section.p: Given a formula we are really just a step away from thinking of functions. While a function has some extra mathematical properties, we can really think of a function f(x) as the label for a particular calculation involving the quantity x. The major string attached to this designation is that a particular x-value can only give rise to a single calculated value.

Imagine referring to the calculation of the quantity (50+x)(50+x), it would be a bit of a drag if, any time that we wanted to make reference to the calculation, we had to refer to the complete formula. Instead we could assign this special calculation to a function f(x) = (50+x)(50+x), at which point we could refer to our action by either the formula or the function name. Setting x = 3 and calculating we could say ''lets take the quantity 50 plus 3 times the quantity 50 plus 3'' to calculate a particular value. As a much more convenient alternative we could simply say f(3), the value of the function whose formula defines the calculation.

Now, a major source of confusion about functions lies in the notation itself. In particular, parentheses show up in two places, with two different meanings, \underbrace{f(x)}_{\text{function notation}}= \underbrace{(50 + x)(50 + x)}_{\text{grouping and multiplication}} We read the notation f(x) as ''f of x'' referring to the value generated by a particular choice of x; these parentheses serve as `function notation'. In contrast, each pair of parentheses on the right (''(50 + x)'') serve as grouping the two terms to be added; abutting these two factors indicates a step of multiplying the results of the two completed addition operations.

As an added example of the use and misuse of parenthesis with respect to function notation consider the natural logarithm function \ln(x). When solving equations that require the application of natural logarithms for simplification, novice users often write things like 3\cdot \ln when they mean, or should mean, \ln(3). This can be contrasted with how we use the square root symbol `\sqrt{\phantom{8}}'. To take the square root of 8, we would always write `\sqrt{8}' and not `8\cdot\sqrt{\phantom{8}}.'

Sometimes we say y = f(x) to indicate that a particular function f(x) generates a value called y, to form an ordered pair (x, y). Occasionally we try to use more meaningful symbols than y, f, and x. For example, in discussing our pace we could somewhat generically write a function f(x) = 0.3218x. This gives very little insight into the meaning of the symbol x or the result of the calculation. We might then say p = f(x) = 0.3218, just as we have said y = f(x) =0.3218 in many instances before. Better yet would be p = p(x) = 0.3218, where the function and variable name are the same - one fewer thing to keep track of - and indicative of the measurement of `pace'. Better still would be p = p(t) = 0.3218t were the variable t could be a reminder of the measurement of time.

Given a function there are really two things we might do
''plug in'' or evaluate with a known input value
set up and solve an equation for an unknown input value
The first of these tends to be a bit easier, the second can be much harder (or in some cases impossible using or typical methods).

statement.p: In this case, given \text{any} value for x we can evaluate our function f(x) = (50+x)(50+x). For example, taking x=6 we write f(6) = (50+6)(50+6) = (56)(56) = 3136 and read ''f of 6 equals the quantity 50 plus 6 times the quantity 50 plus 6.'' We plug in 6 for every instance of x on the left-hand side and the right hand side. We then use arithmetic operations to calculate the value of the expression on the right-hand side. For x=0 we find f(0) = (50+0)(50+0) = (50)(50) = 2500.

section.title: Imagine
section.p: \footnote{Imagine because we won't actually devote too much time to this from an algebraic perspective.}">--> One of the things we do with functions is set up and solve equations. With this in mind we want to think about the mechanics of how we actually solve the equations and what the solutions might mean.

section.title: Finding your roots
section.p: Here `roots' refers to the zeros of a function f(x) or the solutions to the equation f(x) = 0. This is the set of all numbers (associated to a particular function) for which plugging in these values returns the function value of zero. This can be most easily pictured as where the graph of a function crosses the horizontal axis, though this isn't always enough.

Thinking of a formula such as y = 3x-7 we remind ourselves that there are two things we can do: `plug in' or solve an equation. Suppose we know that x = 4, what can we do with this information? We can evaluate right-hand side to say that when x=4, y = 3(4)- 7 = 12 - 7 = 5. Often when we talk about such formulas we think of them as functions, for example, we might prefer to say y = f(x) = 3x-7. This really just says we generate a set of function values y that correspond to the set of values x. In this case we might revisit our earlier problem with the notation that f(4) = 3(4)-7 = 12. We have `plugged in' the value x=4 on each side of the function, on the left as a particular value of its argument and on the right in each position that the argument occurs.

The other thing we can do given a formula or function is to calculate an unknown input from a known output. For example, we can answer the question `what is x given that y=17?' Here we begin with 17 = 3x-7 and solve for x. Specifically, \begin{aligned}[t] 17 \amp = 3x-7\\ 17+7 \amp = 3x-7 +7\\ 24 \amp = 3x\\ x \amp = \sfrac{24}{3} = 8 \end{aligned}
Of these two tasks, plugging in or evaluating a function is typically easier than setting up and solving an equation. That is not to say it is easy, but typically easier than the other task.

subsection.title: Square roots new ideas
subsection.p: Way back when we discussed numbers, first the counting numbers, we saw we could add and multiply and remain within that set of numbers. Introducing subtraction required us to think about negative number (and zero). Introducing division required us to think about rational numbers and decimals (and soon after irrational numbers). Assuming we are interested in calculating square roots of numbers in order to identify what number can be multiplied twice to generate another, we have to prepare for yet another complication. If we think of the square root arising in the problem (\underline{\quad})(\underline{\quad}) = 25 we might recognize that a number that can be used in both blanks simultaneously is 5\footnote{It turns out that -5 is a valid choice as well, since (-5)(-5) = 25 also.}. Picturing this multiplication problem we can think of other pairs of similarly related numbers also, \begin{aligned}[t] ({5})({5}) \amp= 25\\ ({3})({3}) \amp= 9\\ ({-1})({-1}) \amp= 1\\ ({-3})({-3}) \amp = 9 \end{aligned} It turns out that there are two ways to generate the value 9 by multiplication: of a 3 with itself and of a -3 with itself. We write \sqrt{9} = \pm3 in order to indicate both possibilities. One thing we might notice is that two positive factors yield in a positive result, but so do two negative factors. A question is, ''what, if anything, can we multiply against itself to generate a negative result?''

The answer to this requires us to think of a new type of number, the imaginary number. Here we say that the imaginary number i is a number such that, i\cdot i = i^2 = -1 or, from the reverse that \sqrt{-1} = i. With this new concept we can build numbers called complex numbers that consist of our typical `real part' combined with a term representing this new `imaginary part'. In general complex numbers are of the form a+bi, where a and b come from our usual sets of numbers; they can be whole numbers, fractions or decimals, positives or negatives.
For the moment we will (try to) accept this concept of a new kind of number, just like we have for others along the way, and practice with it in calculations.

statement.p: Consider the real number 3 and four successive rounds of multiplication by i. \begin{aligned}[t] (3)(i) \amp = 3i\\ (3i)(i) \amp = 3(i^2) = 3(-1) = -3\\ (-3)i \amp = -3i\\ (-3i)(i) \amp = (-3)(i^2) = (-3)(-1) = 3 \end{aligned} In this case multiplication by i flips a the real number 3 back and forth between real and imaginary. Four steps of multiplication sends us back to our starting point. Notice, for example, that i^4 = (i^2)(i^2) = (-1)(-1) = 1. In fact, no matter how we break up stages of this calculation we see that i^4 = 1. So multiplying by i four times or by i^4 one time both yield the same outcome.

Consider the complex number 3+2i and four successive rounds of multiplication by 1+i. \begin{aligned}[t] (3+2i)(1+i) \amp = 3\cdot1+3\cdot i+2i\cdot1 + 2i\cdot i\\ \amp = 3 + 3i + 2i + 2(i^2)\\ \amp = 3 + 3i + 2i + 2(-1)\\ \amp = 3 + 5i - 2\\ \amp 1 + 5i \end{aligned} Now the point that used to be at coordinates (3, 2) has moved to the point at coordinates (-1, 5). Convince yourself that one additional multiplication moves the point to (-4,6) corresponding to the complex number -4+6i.

We visualize these steps in the image below, where j refers to the number of steps of multiplication.
Complex numbers.

subsection.p: We can visualize this multiplication by constructing the complex plane: two perpendicular axes, one that describes real values and one that describes imaginary values, which collectively describe all of the complex numbers. Plotting these values in the complex plane and tracing out the steps of multiplication, we can convince ourselves that each step multiplication by i serves to rotate our number counterclockwise around the origin of the graph. Here our numbers lie on the axes (which are perpendicular to one another), so tracking the rotations might be pictured a bit more easily than it can be in general.

subsection.p: Complex numbers are typically first encountered in algebra when working with solutions to quadratic equations (but historically it seems that they were first `invented' or realized when working with cubic equations). Focusing on just the quadratic equations, analytical (i.e., on paper) solutions to ax^2+bx+c=0 can generally be found by factoring, completing the square, or applying the quadratic formula.

We may remember the quadratic formula as x = \frac{x = -b\pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a} Without imaginary and complex numbers, we run into trouble when the term in the square root, called the `discriminant', is negative because without them we could not take the square root. Indeed, solutions are complex numbers if b^2 -4ac \lt 0 this means we can solve the equation in terms of complex numbers, but that the graph will not actually cross the horizontal axis as we are used to seeing happen.

Stepping aside, now that we have a need for square roots and an appreciation of the connection to complex numbers, we will look at the generation of fractals. The mathematical details of this will happen behind the scenes, but the connection from complex numbers to fractals is a strong one. After a brief discussion of fractals, we will return to the world of real numbers, but look at the effects of repetition or iteration on some more concrete problems.

subsection.title: Repeated approximation
subsection.p: Having seen square roots arise in solving certain algebraic problems (quadratic equations) or just certain arithmetic problems (square roots of numbers), we will pause to think about how we might actually calculate square roots of arbitrary numbers. We might know that because 5\cdot5=25 that we can say \sqrt{25} = 5 this is true and reflects the `principal square root'. But, we also have that (-5)\cdot(-5) = 25 and in general say \sqrt{25} = \pm 5 to indicate both ways of squaring a number to get 25. Certain numbers we can take square roots of mentally by thinking about the repeated factors that give rise to that number, but for others we are unable to easily do so.

For example, what is the \sqrt{3}? At the start we might observe that 1\cdot1 = 1 and 2\cdot2=4. We might believe that the answer, the number that we multiply by itself to result in a value of 3, should be between 1 and 2, perhaps even a little closer to 2 than to 1. In a very surprising coincidence, the mathematical technique, and even the more general approach, that lets us approximate \sqrt{3} is actually the same as the one that generated our fractals. A technique called Newton's Method, when applied to this problem, gives a mathematical rule for calculating a sequence of approximations to a square root. The rule is given by x_{n+1} = \frac{1}{2}\left(x_n+\frac{\alpha}{x_n}\right) where x_n is the n^\text{th} approximation to the square root. We imagine x_n as a sequence (or ordered list) of numbers starting at n=0 with a value x_0 and continuing as n grows by one at a time.

statement.p:
Assuming that our \alpha = 3 in our hopes of approximating \sqrt{3}, we might start by guessing that x_0 = 1 and noticing that the step after step n=0 is step n+1 = 0+1 = 1, such that \begin{aligned}[t] x_{0+1} \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(x_0+\frac{3}{x_0}\right)\\ x_1 \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{3}{1}\right)\\ \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(4\right)\\ x_1 \amp = 2 \end{aligned} Now starting from x_1 = 2 we take another step to calculate x_2. \begin{aligned}[t] x_{1+1} \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(x_1+\frac{3}{x_1}\right)\\ x_2 \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(2+\frac{3}{2}\right)\\ \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{7}{2}\right)\\ x_2 \amp = \frac{7}{4} = 1.75 \end{aligned} Repeating this some more (one last time in greater detail), \begin{aligned}[t] x_3 \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{7}{4}+\frac{3}{\sfrac{7}{4}}\right)\\ \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{7}{4}+\frac{3}{1}\cdot\frac{4}{7}\right)\\
\amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{7}{4}+\frac{12}{7}\right)\\ \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{7}{7}\cdot\frac{7}{4}+\frac{4}{4}\cdot\frac{12}{7 }\right)\\ \amp= \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{49 + 48}{28}\right)\\ x_3 \amp= \frac{97}{56}\approx 1.732143 \end{aligned}

Continuing this it might help to visualize the results in a table. Additionally it will no longer make sense to store exact fractions at any step, since our computers are unable to do so anyway. This does save us from having to do things like find common denominators, but does require us to write down some fairly lengthy decimal numbers at times.

introduction.p:
Word problems get a bad rap.
What goes where?
What even matters?
Formatting numbers (e.g., is it 50\% or 0.50?)
''I have to think!?!''
Show your work.
Problems are time-consuming.
Interpretation of answer often required.
But, work problems are an idealized version of most real-world problem solving; in this case we know the course or book we are studying, the unit or chapter, and the topic or section. So, it should be the case that we know roughly what to do, even if we do not exactly know how to do it mechanically.

subsection.title: Life is a word problem
subsection.p: Mathematical modeling is the art, and science, of writing and studying your own word problems about interesting situations. We 1) take real-world knowledge, 2) identify, often with the help of experts, seemingly important facts and details, 3) develop a verbal or visual `story' about what is happening, 4) translate the words and diagrams to mathematical notation and formulas, and 5) study the math problem and see what we have learned. This process is visualized in Fig. \ref{fig::modeling}.

As we generate results, we compare those to the original mathematical problem for consistency, then to the details of the biological problem. If those first two stages are successful, we see if there is anything that can be said about the real-world problem. If not, we revise our assumptions, model, or analysis and try again. Here failure is expected and provides a valuable chance to learn.

Unlike when we find ourselves solving word problems, here we do not know the tool we are supposed to use. It requires a broad training with a diverse set of techniques to pursue mathematical modeling. Almost always one of these tools is a computer and an ability to edit and write computer programs.

Mathematical modeling of infectious disease Nearly every year we are faced with a newly emerged or reemerged infectious pathogen somewhere around the planet. This is a math problem, though one shared with experts from many other disciplines. During the current coronavirus outbreak, caused by the pathogen known as COVID19, mathematicians, some acting as mathematicians and others more as statisticians, have featured prominently. Mathematicians (and specialty-statisticians often referred to as epidemiologists) and others are using the best available knowledge about the virus, its origin, its transmission, and its effect on the infected, to try to understand the pace of the current outbreak and to try to understand its future.

Many tools, most with mathematical and statistical roots, are coming together to help interpret biological data (e.g., virus genetics, patient responses) and population-level `public health' data (e.g., infections across geographic borders). Any time you see a graph of cases plotted against time or deaths plotted against cases, or see the phrase R_0 (the British `naught' for 0, so ''R-naught''), you are seeing the results of mathematical reasoning or analysis. Specifically the quantity R_0 characterizes how infectious a pathogen is expected to be and gives the expected number of cases that one infectious person might cause in a completely susceptible population.

The simplest example of a mathematical model, represented by the diagram in , tracks the amount of a population that is susceptible to infection and those that have the infection and are infectious. The Greek symbols in the diagram denote parameters and each symbol is acting as placeholder for a particular number that is important to understanding how the possible outbreak unfolds. Of the two numbers, \beta is slightly more complicated and attempts to summarize how frequently individuals interact and how likely it is that one of those interactions results in transmission; \gamma is less complicated and reflects how long a person remains infectious (i.e., it describes a `recovery rate').

section.title: Modeling with functions
section.p: If we are ultimately interested in modeling using mathematical functions, we need to build up a catalog of mathematical functions. Before we diversify too much, we will spend a but of time looking at quadratic functions. Quadratic functions f(x) = ax^2 + bx + c coupled with the quadratic formula x = \dfrac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} which gives the x values that solve f(x) = 0. What is surprising, perhaps, is just how often and in how many places the quadratic formula shows up as the lynchpin of so many mathematical problems. Partly this is because so many problems are ultimately studied in two dimensions. For example, we are used to visualizing so many problems in the xy-plane.

Specifically we are looking for the numbers x and y that simultaneously satisfy these equations. We could solve for one variable from one equation and substitute into the other equation to solve. Alternatively, we could solve each equation for y, graph, and look for the intersection. Proceeding in this direction, \begin{aligned}[t] 2x+3y\amp=7\\ 3y \amp = 7 - 2x\\ y \amp = -\dfrac{2}{3}x+\dfrac{7}{3} \end{aligned} Similarly from the second equation, \begin{aligned}[t] 5x+4y\amp=9\\ 4y \amp = 9 - 5x\\ y \amp = -\dfrac{5}{4}x+\dfrac{9}{4} \end{aligned}

We could start by graphing one of these, perhaps the second, whose graph is a straight line with slope of m=-\sfrac{5}{4} and y-intercept of b=\sfrac{9}{4}. The graph of the line starts at a value of \sfrac{9}{4} on the y-axis, from there we go down 5 units for every 5 units we move to the right (we could also picture going down \sfrac{5}{4} units for every 1 we move to the right). We could superimpose a graph of the other and identify the intersection, which corresponds to the solution to the system of equations.

subsection.title: Another approach
subsection.p: Using some very different methods, we could rewrite the system \begin{aligned}[t] \begin{cases} 2x+3y \amp = 7\\ 5x+4y \amp = 9 \end{cases} \end{aligned} in matrix-vector form as follows, \left(\begin{array}{cc}2 \amp 3 \\ 5 \amp 4\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}x\\y\end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{c}7\\9\end{array}\right) To confirm that these are equal we perform matrix-vector multiplication. To recover the first equation in the system we multiply the entries in the first row by x and y and add between each step of multiplication. The result is equal to the top entry on the right-hand side, the 7.

With this square arrangement of numbers, the matrix, we enter the field of linear algebra (note: very closely associated with linear algebra, especially in two dimensions, is the study of differential equations). Linear algebra plays an essential role in differential equations, and by association, so does the quadratic formula.} which is broadly concerned with techniques for solving linear systems of equations. Often we are less concerned with the solutions to linear systems and we are more concerned with properties of the matrix itself. One such property of the matrix actually requires us to calculate solutions to an associated quadratic equation using the quadratic formula. To say it again, there is a direct connection between 2D matrices (2 rows, 2 columns) and the quadratic formula.

section.title: Catalog of mathematical functions

subsection.title: Linear-functions
subsection.p:
Linear functions are those of the form y = f(x) = mx+b, we call m the slope and b the y-coordinate of the y-intercept. We can solve equations of evaluate functions. Graphs of linear functions are straight lines. If the slope is positive, the line increases from left to right (bigger x results in bigger y). If the slope is negative, the line decreases from left to right (bigger x results in smaller y). If the slope is zero, the line is flat or constant.
Graph of an increasing linear function.
Graph of an decreasing linear function.
Graph of an flat or constant linear function.
Linear functions are often used in regression to determine the slope and intercept of a line that best summarize information in a scatterplot of points.

statement.p: A popular example of a linear function is F = \dfrac{9}{5}C + 32 which describes the temperature in degrees Fahrenheit as a function of temperature in degrees Celsius. We might remember that the freezing point of water is 32 {}^\circ\text{F} and that the boiling point is 212 {}^\circ\text{F}. We might be interested in representing these values in Celsius, and can pursue this by solving each of the following equations for C, \begin{aligned}[t] 32 \amp = \dfrac{9}{5}C+32\\ 212 \amp = \dfrac{9}{5}C+32 \end{aligned} To solve each, we subtract 32 from each side and then multiply by \dfrac{5}{9} to find that the freezing point of water os 0 {}^\circ\text{C} and the bioling point is 100 {}^\circ\text{C}. For example, \begin{aligned}[t] 32 \amp = \dfrac{9}{5}C+32\\ \cancel{32-32} \amp = \dfrac{9}{5}C+\cancel{32 - 32}\\ 0 \amp = \dfrac{9}{5}C\\ \dfrac{5}{9}\cdot0 \amp = \cancel{\dfrac{5}{9}\cdot\dfrac{9}{5}}C\\ C \amp = 0 \end{aligned}

subsection.exercise: Repeat the calculation to confirm the boiling point of water in Celsius.

statement.p: Consider you are taking a \sout{taxi} Lime scooter ride. The \sout{taxi"> Lime scooter charges a $1.00 `unlock fee' then charges an additional $0.29 per minute. Write the linear function that describes cost c as function of time spend riding t.

example.solution: We can imagine in words that the cost is equal to the initial charge plus the cost per minute multiplied by the number of minutes. This is c = c(t) = (\text{initial charge}) + (\text{cost per minute})(\text{time spent riding}) or c = c(t) = 1.00 + 0.29t

subsection.p: We can ask our usual sorts of questions about this function. For example ''What if we made the poor decision to skip class and go on a 75-minute camps joyride? How much would this cost?''

statement.p: ''What if we made the poor decision to skip class and go on a 75-minute campus joyride instead? How much would this cost?''

example.solution: To answer this question, we evaluate c(75) to find the associated cost. \begin{aligned}[t] c(75) \amp = 1.00 + 0.29(75)\\ \amp= 22.75 \end{aligned}

subsection.p: Or, ''How long could I ride if I had a $5 credit?''

statement.p: ''How long could I ride if I had a $5 credit?''

example.solution: To answer this question, we solve c(t) = 5 for the unknown value of t. \begin{aligned}[t] %5 \amp = c(t) \\ 5 \amp= 1.00 + 0.29t\\ 4.00 \amp= 0.29t\\ t\amp= \dfrac{4.00}{0.29} = 13.79\\ \end{aligned}

section.subsection:
Quadratic functions
...
The simplest quadratic function is f(x) = x^2, whose graph is a `u'-shaped parabola (as opposed to `n'-shaped). This term is an example of a power function, built from a variable raised to a number as a power, x^2 \text{ is of the form } (\text{variable})^\text{number}. This form has important consequences for the properties of the formula and its use in applications. With similar terms we can construct polynomial functions such as, g(x) = 3x^2+x^4 which are sums of constants multiplied by powers of a variable.
Quadratic functions show up frequently in applications, for example in physics. We often study problems such as s(t) = -4.9t^2 + 10t + 12 where s(t) represents the height of an object thrown from a height of 12 \text{meters} with an initial velocity of 10 \text{meters per second}. Because the number in front of t^2 is negative, the graph of the corresponding parabola opens downward (as an upside down `u'). There are a few ways that we can learn a little more about the graph to determine the position of the curve within the t-s plane (that is, in a plot of s against t).
Notice that when t = 0, s(0) = -4.9(0)^2 + 10(0) + 12 = 10; the graph of s(t) crosses the vertical axis at a value of 12. But given the shape of the curve (an upside-down parabola), does the graph intersect the point (0, 12) on its downstroke, at its vertex, or on its upstroke? There are a number of ways to answer this question
`cheat' and graph the formula using a computer (e.g., with Desmos online, or even Google!) or graphing calculator
put the function in vertex form
apply methods of calculus
explore the formula using a hodge-podge of approaches
We will take the last of these approaches. A question is (not unrelated to how we might reason about functions using calculus or even more sophisticated approaches) is ''what does the graph look like when t is ''small''?'' Here we mean t\approx0 to give an estimate of what we consider to be ''small'' values of t. Here thinking numerically about the relative contribution of each term gives some indication of the value of the function in general. The values of each term and the exact and approximate values of each function are given in Table \ref{tab::position}.

The results in Tab. XX (are not shown because they weren't particularly helpful) suggests that the height is initially increasing (by the exact values, or by the approximation). The approximation, neglecting the contribution of the t^2 term for small values of t suggests that the position initially increases in an approximately linear fashion. At some point though, the quadratic term starts to play a role. It seems quite strange that s(10) = -378, this would suggest that the object is 378 \text{meters} below the surface of the ground. It should be the case that at some point prior, the model stops making sense. In fact, we could use the quadratic formula to determine when the object lands. Solving for s(t) = 0 gives the value(s) of time t for which the height from the ground is zero. \begin{aligned}[t] x \amp= \dfrac{-10\pm\sqrt{10^2 - 4(-4.9)(12)}}{2(-4.9)}\\ \amp = \dfrac{-10\pm\sqrt{335.2}}{-9.8}\\ x \amp = -0.847,\,\,2.889\\ \end{aligned} The negative value does not make as much sense because this suggests that the object was on the ground \text{before} we threw it upwards - we are only really concerned with the future after t=0. From our hodge-podge analysis we have that the object starts from a height of 12 \text{meters}, increases approximately linearly for a brief span, and with the shape of a parabola eventually comes back down and lands at t\approx2.899. The mathematical equation is valid for all time, but after this the equation as a mathematical object of the flight of the object stops making sense.

subsection.title: Polynomials
subsection.p: As mentioned in the previous section, g(x) = 3x^2+x^4 is an example of a polynomial. This category can be written as a sum of multiples of powers of a variable, for example p_n(x) = \sum_{i=0}^n a_i x_i where in the example for g(x) we would have n=4 with a_0 = a_1 = a_3 = 0, and a_2 = 3 and a_4 = 1. In summation form, g(x) = \sum_{i=0}^4 a_i x^i = 0x^0 + 0x^1 + 3x^2 + 0x^3 + 1x^4 = 3x^2 + x^4

Applications of polynomials are numerous, this stems partly from the fact that they are `easy' to evaluate. The word `easy' refers to the fact that there might be many, many terms to keep track of, but that it only requires elementary operations of addition or subtraction and multiplication. As a consequence, polynomials play an important role in how we evaluate most functions using calculators or computers.
As a few examples of polynomials, consider f(x) = x^3 and g(x) = x^3-x. In the second of these, the subtraction of x has a dramatic impact on the graph (see ).

figure.caption: The graph of f(x) = x^3 crosses the horizontal axis only once.
The graph of g(x) = x^3-x crosses the horizontal axis at three distinct values.

subsection.p: Side-by-side, the graph of f(x) = x^3 is relatively less interesting than that of g(x) = x^3 - x. Given a sketch, it appears that x^3 only has one zero, while x^3-x has three zeroes. In general it isn't as easy to use something like the quadratic formula for solutions to polynomial equations with higher powers. Here however, we get a bit lucky and can do some factoring of x^3-x. It turns out that in solving this, we can write x(x^2-1)= 0 as a first step. To solve this equation either factor can be zero. From the first factor we have x=0, additionally from the second we can solve x^2-1=0 to find the locations of other solutions. We have three strategies, guessing solutions, attempting to factor, or applying the quadratic formula (the second equation is a quadratic after all).

If we factor, we might notice this as a difference of squares (x^2 and 1 can each be written as squares, of x and 1, respectively). We have x^2-1 = (x+1)(x-1) From here we set each factor to zero to find the x values that solve this equation and the original equation. The value are x = -1 and x=1, or x=\pm 1. Alternatively we could apply the quadratic formula to this quadratic with a = 1, b=0, and c=-1 \begin{aligned}[t] x \amp= \dfrac{-0\pm\sqrt{0^2 - 4(1)(-1)}}{2(1)}\\ \amp = \dfrac{\pm\sqrt{4}}{2}\\ x \amp = \pm 1\\ \end{aligned} Taking a peek back at the original formula for g(x) = x^3-x we might notice we could have originally factored this as g(x) = x(x+1)(x-1) (we can multiply this out to check that it agrees with the original formula). The factored form illustrates that for g(x) = 0 any one of the factors can be zero, each of which agrees with our solutions above.

subsection.title: Power functions
subsection.p: In some sense power functions are simpler than polynomials, they only contain a single term. But often that term is less familiar than those that occur in polynomials. For example, we might be interested in f(x) = x^{0.5} or g(x) = x^{0.75} where are non-integer powers of the variable of interest. These functions take on very different shapes and are useful in a variety of situations. The square root function is an example of a power function \sqrt{x} = x^{0.5} which has the shape of a `sideways parabola', x^1 = x is another (a straight line), x^2 which has the shape of a normal parabola, as well as x raised to any other power. We can also put a constant factor out in front, for example f(x) = 1.4x^{0.24}

Power functions are often used as formulas to represent simple nonlinear patterns. Three classic examples are species-area accumulation curves, the skull length-backbone length relationship in fossil fish, and the connection between the metabolism-body mass relationship of mammals and the accidental overdoes of an elephant with LSD.

subsection.title: Kleiber's Law curve
subsection.p: In terms of energy use (i.e., metabolism), a mouse must eat half of its body mass per day in order to survive, an elephant much less. In fact, the energy metabolism, E, of an animal as a function of its body mass, M, is described by E = (\#)M^{0.75} This relationship holds across a remarkable range of organism sizes and was originally built by trying to understand the relationship between the surface area (amount of skin) and volume (amount within the skin).

subsection.title: Rational functions
subsection.p: Rational functions are any ratios of two separate polynomials. For example, r(x) = \dfrac{-4.9x^2+10x+12}{x^3-x} is a rational function. These functions can take on a variety of interesting and useful shapes as graphs.

subsection.title: Exponentials and Logarithms
subsection.p: Most importantly is that we recognize that exponential functions are of the form (\text{number})^\text{variable} in contrast to power functions which are of the form (\text{variable})^\text{number} Exponential functions (see Fig. \ref{fig::exp}) seem to be frequently confused with quadratic functions (see Fig. \ref{fig::power}). Looking at the graphs however, the quadratic has a symmetry (for x^2 a fold along the vertical axis) that the exponentials lack.

statement.p: Exponential functions show up in a variety of places, such as population growth. A return to paperfolding provides a somewhat surprising connection to exponential functions. Taking the thickness of a piece of paper after fold number n to be represented by t_n, we can track the thickness of the paper as we fold. For example, t_1 = 2t_0 = 2(0.01) = 0.02 and t_2 = 2t_1 = 2(0.02) = 0.04 After n folds we actually have doubled n times, and can write t_n = 2^n(t_0) This is precisely exponential growth, as illustrated in Table \ref{tab::paper}. Since the width is divided in half after each fold, we can also calculate the remaining width of paper in a similar manner. \begin{table"> \centering \caption{Thickness and width of standard copy paper after n folds.}\label{tab::paper">

\begin{tabular}{ccc"> number of folds, n \amp thickness of paper, t_n (\text{mm}) \amp width of paper (mm)\\ \hline\hline 0 \amp 0.01 \amp 27.94\\ 1 \amp 0.02 \amp 13.97\\ 2 \amp 0.04 \amp 6.99\\ 3 \amp 0.08 \amp 3.49\\ 4 \amp 0.16 \amp 1.75\\ 5 \amp 0.32 \amp 0.87\\ 6 \amp 0.64 \amp 0.44\\ 7 \amp 1.28 \amp 0.22\\ 8 \amp 2.56 \amp 0.11 \end{tabular"> \end{table-->

An easily overlooked complication lies in Table \ref{tab::paper}: by the sixth fold, the paper is actually thicker than it is wide. There is no longer enough paper to fold! Assuming that we could fold the paper 100 times, it would be 1.268\times10^{28} \text{mm} (or 1.268\times10^{22} \text{kilometers}) thick! These results, are illustrated in Fig. \ref{fig::paper_exp}. The diameter of the earth is 1.2742\times10^4 \text{kilometers}, so this result is shocking if not almost incomprehensible.

subsection.p: As a follow-up to exponential functions are logarithmic functions. Recall that we can think of the logarithm of some number of interest as the power to which we raise another number to get that number of interest. For example, in terms of powers of 10, 10^4 = 10,000 \text{can be expressed as} \log_{10}(10,000) = 4 Each of these translates to the understanding that 4 factors of 10 is ten thousand or 10 to the fourth power is 10,000. Similarly the relationship 2^4 = 16 \text{can be expressed as} \log_2(16) = 4

In addition to thinking of single calculations of logarithms of numbers, we can talk about logarithm functions. We plot the graph of the natural logarithm in Fig. \ref{fig::ln}. The natural logarithm \ln(x) gives the exponent to to which we raise e to arrive at the argument of the natural logarithm.

subsection.title: Mathematical-modeling-reprise
subsection.p:
When modeling spread of something infectious (a pathogen, a rumor, a behavior) we break a population into relevant groups. One of the simplest breakdowns is into groups of
susceptible (these are the `healthy' people)
infectious
recovered
There are some subtleties here that I will mention, but not spend any more time on. The name of the group `infectious' suggests that these individuals are not only infected, but are also capable of transmitting their infection to others. The `recovered' group is sometimes called `removed' to indicate the group of individuals that are removed from the process of infection either by natural recovery or death.

The way infection is modeled is by a system of differential equations which describe how the number of individuals within each population is assumed to change over time, as individuals flow between groups. A diagram of the possible transitions is given in .

When we try to translate these assumptions into a mathematical model we begin with \begin{aligned}[t] \text{change in susceptible} \amp = -\text{(people getting sick)} + \text{(people losing imunity)}\\ \text{change in infectious} \amp = + \text{(people getting sick)} - \text{(people recovering)} - \text{(people dying from infection)}\\ \text{change in recovered} \amp = + \text{(people recovering)} - \text{(people losing immunity)} \end{aligned} We translate this to more mathematical language involving some calculus as follows \begin{aligned}[t] \dfrac{dS}{dt}\amp = -\beta S I + \rho R\\ \dfrac{dI}{dt} \amp = \beta S I - \gamma I - \delta I\\ \dfrac{dR}{dt} \amp = \gamma I - \rho R \end{aligned} The specific equations are not of great importance here, but you could hopefully imagine that the number of new infections depends on the number that are susceptible to infection (S) and the number that can transmit infection (I), so in some way the amount of new infections combines those two values. Similarly, the number of individuals that recover should depend on the amount that are infectious and the number of individuals that lose immunity should depend on the number that have recovered.

The Greek letters are called `parameters'; these are symbols used to represent various numbers like the transmission parameter \beta or the recovery rate \gamma (see Table \ref{tab::epi}). Sometimes it is easier to write and study the model generically without having to worry about the precise decimal values that go in these positions, so we use the Greek letters as placeholders. This is similar to how we use the formula y=mx+b to describe a linear function between variables y and x. Whether or not we have acknowledged this before, m and b are parameters of the linear formula (`slope' and `y-intercept', respectively). Changes to these numbers might change the appearance, but do not change the fundamental nature of the relationship between y and x.

Models have been used as decision-making tools worldwide. Models have been both fairly and unfairly criticized. Graphs, tables, jargon have showed up everywhere.
